report_title: Gear & Speed Changer Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: The Gear and Speed Changer Manufacturing industry makes power transmission equipment and gears used in the production processes of different downstream manufacturers. End users, which include food and beverage processors, paper manufacturers, plastic manufacturers and construction contractors, require power transmission equipment and gears to outfit their equipment. Through 2023, the pandemic created high economic uncertainty, suppressing consumer spending. Overall economic activity declined, slowing industrial production and weakening demand for the industry's products. Overall, revenue will stagnate to an estimated $4.2 billion through 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Unsteady Manufacturing Growth Has Stifled Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: This industry primarily supplies intermediary components to other manufacturers; the gear and speed changer manufacturing strengthens when downstream markets expand production. The Paper Mills industry (IBISWorld report 32212) buys high-speed industrial drivers to manufacture paper products, including printing, writing, newsprint, packaging and household papers. As consumers have switched to online communication, cutting out paper, this market has crashed, forcing gear and speed changer manufacturers to shift production to cater to other industries.

The appreciation of the US dollar has hindered the industry through the current period. As the value of the US dollar grows relative to other currencies, US goods and services become less affordable and desirable for foreign markets. Notably, import penetration accounts for more than 70.0% of domestic demand. Imports from low-wage countries, like China, outcompete domestic products, while German and Japanese products can match the quality of domestic manufacturers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile Input Prices Cut Into Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Steel, alongside ferrous and nonferrous metals, like aluminum and copper, are vital inputs for gear and speed changer manufacturers. Increasing volatility in steel and aluminum prices has created uncertainty, especially as supply chains contracted following the pandemic. For example, world steel prices skyrocketed more than 110.0% in 2021. Many manufacturers could pass on rising costs to buyers, generating massive revenue increases in 2021 and 2022. Even so, these costs have slammed profit, causing it to plummet more than 41.0% in 2021 alone.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Many manufacturers have introduced new products to complement new technology, especially green energy generation, like wind and hydroelectric. Magnetic Gears: A Disruptive Technology - Traditional gears for electricity generation interlock, generating kinetic energy with every rotation. Mechanical gears often carry high maintenance costs and create considerable acoustic noise and vibrations, making them inoperable in populated areas and disrupting animal behavior.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Domestic Companies Expand into Emerging Markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the US dollar depreciates over the next few years, imports will become less attractive to domestic customers, creating breathing room for gear and speed changer manufacturers. Major domestic markets will face less pressure to choose between more expensive, superior-quality domestic products and inexpensive, inferior-quality overseas products. Many emerging markets will also demand more gears and speed changers to support growing manufacturing sectors.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers Will Rely on the Recovery of Downstream Markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry depends on demand from other industrial manufacturers, ranging from food processors to heavy machinery and turbine manufacturers. Many of these industries struggled during the pandemic as end use markets closed or cut demand. As the economy and supply chains recover, downstream manufacturers will increase production, purchasing more gears and speed changers.

industry_definition: This industry includes establishments engaged in manufacturing gears, speed changers and industrial high-speed drives. These components are used primarily in mechanical power transmissions for industrial machines or vehicles. This industry does not include passenger automobile transmission manufacturing.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level medium - steady

threats: Import penetration into the manufacturing sector

key_trends: A large portion of the overall decline in manufacturing demand can be attributed to declines in machinery manufacturing
As downstream demand is sated, industry revenue declines are to be expected
Despite an overall improvement in profitability, recent declines in revenue have decreased industry participation
Operators are anticipated to benefit from improving global economic conditions

market_segmentation.segment_description: Nearly all manufacturing sectors like food, chemical and metal use gears and power transmission equipment. Manufacturers often secure long-term contracts.
Some companies sell to distributors and wholesalers who act as intermediaries, but this segment is declining as manufacturers bypass wholesalers.
Equipment rental companies buy products to maintain fleets. Repair services buy parts and accessories as replacing equipment is expensive.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Speed changers and industrial high-speed drives
products_and_services.product_description: Power transmission equipment like speed reducers, gear motors and industrial drives used to control machinery speeds.
Gear varieties like helical, worm, bevel and spur gears as well as racks and pinions used to transfer power.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Parts and accessories for gear and speed changers
products_and_services.product_description: Standardized replacement parts and accessories that improve productivity and efficiency, often cheaper than replacing equipment.

tier_1_suppliers: Nonferrous Metal Refining in the US
Nonferrous Metal Rolling & Alloying in the US
Metalworking Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Printing, Paper, Food, Textile & Other Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Construction Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Woodworking Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Plastics & Rubber Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Semiconductor Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Pump & Compressor Manufacturing in the US
Power Tools & Other General Purpose Machinery Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The manufacturing sector is the primary market, heavily driving demand. Capital investment in industrial equipment and machinery is an essential driver.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Domestic manufacturers face price competition from low-cost exporters like China. High-quality imports from Germany and Japan are less expensive due to strong dollar.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports to Canada enjoy major uptick
international_trade_points.trade_description: In 2019, exports to Canada increased due to oil/gas extraction in Alberta requiring machinery with gears and speed changers.
Nearly half of exports go to Mexico/Canada due to USMCA lowering transportation costs and tariffs between the three nations.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has the highest concentration of establishments since it is a manufacturing hub and close to Canada, a major export destination.
The Mid-Atlantic region has many garment and paper manufacturers that use gears and speed changers. It is also close to Canada and major ports for trade with Europe.
The Southeast region has a high population providing labor. It is a trade hub through the Gulf of Mexico and Atlantic Ocean with many major ports.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Like the manufacturing sector, this industry is subject to environmental regulations enforced by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The Clean Air Act limits emissions produced during the manufacturing process.

The Clean Water Act regulates the discharge of pollutants into surface water; the act establishes a system of minimum national efficiency standards on an industry-to-industry basis, water quality standards and a discharge permit program.

Manufacturers are also subject to various nonenvironmental matters, including occupational health and safety, wage, overtime and other employment matters dealing with state and federal government agencies.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Incumbents have extensive patent portfolios. Prospective entrants need to acquire patents or conduct in-house research. Companies must comply with environmental and worker safety regulations.
Entrants struggle to compete with incumbents with an established reputation for quality products and contracts with downstream manufacturers.
New facilities and energy costs are major start-up expenses. Companies must also purchase specialized equipment to produce gears and speed changers.
Skilled workers, particularly for research and development, command premium wages. Many entrants struggle to draw in skilled labor.

basis_points.basis_description: Companies face heavy price competition from imports, as downstream industries prefer less expensive products if quality differences are negligible.
Manufacturers with streamlined manufacturing and input costs can charge a lower price. Companies can also reduce manufacturing costs through acquisitions and economies of scale savings.
Companies can curtail input prices by establishing close relationships with upstream ferrous and nonferrous metal manufacturers.
Gear and speed changer manufacturers compete on product quality as these are long-term capital investments for downstream industries.
Manufacturers can improve product quality by expanding research and development into creating the most effective manufacturing technique and gear technology.
Companies compete on the ability to acquire patents, as this prevents competitors from copying an effective technology.

concentration_points.concentration_description: In late 2022, Regal Rexnord announced its acquisition of Altra Industrial Motion Corp. The new conglomerate will make up more than 60.0% of the market.
Following Regal Rexnord's acquisition of Altra, the two remaining powerhouses have cornered nearly the entire market, generating more than 70.0% of total revenue.
These companies leverage economies of scale and existing relationships to keep strong grips on their markets, preventing new companies from expanding.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Manufacturers rely on raw metals like aluminum, copper and steel. Steel and aluminum prices have been highly volatile, massively fluctuating throughout the pandemic and supply chain disruptions.

While companies are susceptible to changes in the cost of input materials, successful manufacturers mitigate price swings with supply contracts and pass on expenses to consumers. These contracts often contain a fixed price or price ceiling on supply costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Gear and Speed Changer Manufacturing industry has moderate capital intensity. In addition to acquiring, maintaining and updating specialized technical equipment, companies must have access to competitively priced raw materials, like aluminum, copper and steel. At the same time, companies require a skilled workforce.

New entrants must be able to attract skilled labor, especially technical engineers, which represents a significant cost. Manufacturers also need research and development teams to develop new technologies to remain competitive.

Companies will spend an estimated $0.19 on capital for every $1.00 spent on labor. Companies that produce on a large scale are more capital-intensive, while smaller manufacturers have lower capital expenditures and greater labor costs.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Manufacturers face exposure to supply chain volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fluctuations in raw material costs contribute to the industry's volatility. Steel, ferrous and nonferrous metal prices skyrocketed amid supply chain shortages, throwing the industry into disarray.
Similarly, the pandemic halted the manufacturing sector's productivity, sending the industry into a nosedive. As manufacturing capacity recovers, the industry will rally.

volatility_points.volatility_title: IMPORTS CONSTITUTE A SIGNIFICANT THREAT TO THE INDUSTRY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Imports have swarmed the industry. Chinese imports compete heavily with domestic goods on price, while Japanese and German products often match domestic quality.

As the US dollar's value decreases, imports will ease, creating opportunities for domestic manufacturers to recover lost domestic demand. Even so, companies will struggle to compete with foreign manufacturers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Gear and Speed Changer Manufacturing industry has moderate technological change. While most manufacturers emphasize research and development of new technology, most technological breakthroughs focus on improving manufacturing and efficiency, the basic technology behind gears has not significantly changed.

For example, strain wave gearing, also known as harmonic drive, was discovered in 1957; the performance of this gear system remains relatively unchanged. Manufacturers use harmonic drives in motion control, machine tools and printing machines.

Computer technology has improved manufacturing quality and efficiency. Computer-aided design and computer-controlled machine tools have reduced labor costs. Also, any errors during the manufacturing process can greatly reduce the efficiency of gears and power transmission equipment.

Automated manufacturing reduces human manufacturing errors, lowering costs associated with unusable products. Through 2023, the use of computer-aided and automated manufacturing machinery has increased, benefiting this industry.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Import penetration is very high in the industry; many manufacturers have facilities worldwide.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?

The Gear and Speed Changer Manufacturing industry benefits from various import tariffs the federal government sets. General tariffs range from 2.5% to 4.2% and cover gear motors, gears, speed changers and other similar products. Countries without Normal Trade Relations status with the United States, like China and Russia, encounter tariffs that range from 27.5% to 35.0%. Most major trading partners are exempt from tariffs because of free trade agreements.
FAQs.answer: Downstream users of the industry's products rely on inexpensive imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in the price of steel has negatively impacted profit for companies in the industry.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in areas with well-established infrastructure?
FAQs.answer: Acquisitions, especially among major companies in the industry, have increased considerably over the past few years.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology like 3D printing to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Technological change has remained relatively stable in the industry over the past five years. Companies are implementing new manufacturing techniques like using powdered metals to cut costs. Magnetic gears represent a potential disruption within the industry but are still in the development and testing phases.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Wages have increased over the past few years. Companies need skilled labor to innovate high-quality and competitive products.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: The regulatory landscape has remained stable over the past five years. Companies must adhere to environmental and worker safety laws.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: The federal government has enacted tariffs to combat import penetration, especially from China and other low-wage countries. Tariffs have seen limited success since imports satisfy more than two-thirds of domestic demand.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: The industry's average profit has sharply declined as companies combat rising wages, price competition and volatile input costs. Consolidation may increase average profit.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in the price of steel has slashed profit over the past 12 months. As the price of steel ebbs in 2023, profit will stabilize.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to successfully negotiate with the FCC? How quickly would you be able to deal with sanctions?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers must successfully abide by general manufacturing and environmental regulations set by the federal and state governments. Failure to do so results in financial sanctions.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality? Do you update processes in response to customer feedback?
FAQs.answer: Gears and speed changers are long-term capital investments by downstream industries. Successful manufacturers must have superior product quality and longevity.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? How do you reduce product delivery times?
FAQs.answer: Nearly all downstream customers are in the manufacturing sector. Companies located in regions with high industrial concentration can reduce transportation costs.

FAQs.question: How much do you compete with imported products? How can you differentiate your offerings from these foreign competitors?
FAQs.answer: For more than a decade, imports have satisfied an increasing domestic demand for manufactured gear and speed changer products. Imported machinery inputs now supply a significant share of domestic demand in the United States.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuating oil and natural gas prices affect your company? Are you prepared for increased downstream demand from oil and gas operators?
FAQs.answer: A declining oil and natural gas price index represents less revenue for energy companies per unit produced. As it declines, these buyers tend to restrict capital expenditures, which filters back to gear manufacturers that make intermediary components for their machines.

FAQs.question: Do you expect positive trends in the overall number of manufacturers? How do you identify clients who may need replacement products?
FAQs.answer: Income levels, the after-tax cost of replacements, the cost of new equipment, the average age of existing equipment and technological advancements in new equipment influence capital expenditure on machinery and equipment.
